nodes.text: A financial manager can use the combined information in the firm’s income statement and balance sheet to gauge how efficiently his or her firm is utilizing its assets. A first broad measure of efficiency is
The ratio of sales to total assets.
, the ratio of sales to total assets:

data.alt: Asset Turnover equals StartFraction Sales Over Total Assets EndFraction

nodes.text: Low values of asset turnover indicate that the firm is not generating much revenue (sales) per dollar of assets. In 2019, Global’s $170.1 million in assets generated $186.7 million in sales, for an asset turnover ratio of

nodes.text: . Since total assets includes assets, such as cash, that are not directly involved in generating sales, Global’s manager might also look at Global’s fixed asset turnover, which is equal to sales divided by fixed assets:

data.alt: Fixed Asset Turnover equals StartFraction Sales Over Fixed Assets EndFraction

nodes.text: Global’s fixed assets in 2019 were $113.1 million worth of property, plant, and equipment, yielding a fixed asset turnover of

data.mathML: <math alttext="" class="inlineequation" display="inline" altimg="../images/s1altmath_70.png" altimg-height="26" altimg-width="201"><mrow><mn>1.7</mn><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>$186.7</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>$113.1</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></math>

nodes.text: . Low asset turnover ratios indicate that the firm is generating relatively few sales given the amount of assets it employs.
